_header: Well said by corpus dominus quod our Host
Title(s): ‘Shipman-Prioress Link’; Words of the Host to the Shipman and to the Lady Prioress; Canterbury Tales
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the ‘Shipman-Prioress Link’ of the Canterbury Tales — 18 lines in couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
Wel bi corpus dominus seide oure oostnow longe moote
                    thow saile bi the coost…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…now wol ye vouche saf my lady deregladly quod she and seid in
                    this manere
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And / next folwith the Priorasse is first prolog Domine dominus
                        noster (f. 163v); the prolog (RT); Here endith the Priorasse
                    hir first prolog… (f. 164)

BodBar20.First Lines:
Wel saide by corpus dominus quod oure osteNow longe mote þi
                    seileyn by þe se Coste…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…Now wolle ȝe vouche sauf my lady dereGladly quod she and
                    saide in this manere
BodBar20.Attributed Title:
…and here / begynnyth þe prologe of þe prioresse (f.
                        199v); Explicit prologus… (f. 200)

Bod414.First Lines:
[W]Ele seid by corpus dominus quod our hostNow long mot thou
                    saile by the cost…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…Now wil ye vouch saue my ladi dereGladly coth she and seid as
                    ye shul here

Bod686.First Lines:
Wel seyd by corpus dominus quod oure hostNow longe mote þou
                    sayle by þe coost…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…And next if so were þat ye woldeGladly quod she and
                    seyde as ye shal here
Bod686.Attributed Title: …Herken þe now the mery / wordes of the hoost (f. 166)

BodHatDon1.First Lines:
Wel said be corpus dominus quod oure hosNow longe mote þou
                    saile bi þe coost…
BodHatDon1.Last Lines:
…Now wil ye vouchesaue my lady dereGladly quod she and seid in
                    þis manere
BodHatDon1.Attributed Title:
…And next begynneþ / the Prolog of the Prioresse (f.
                        183v); The Prioresse (RT)

BodLauMis600.First Lines:

                    bi þe cost…
BodLauMis600.Last Lines:
…Now wol ye vouchesaf my lady dereGladli quod she and saide in
                    þis manere

BodLauMis739.First Lines:

                    by þe see cost…
BodLauMis739.Last Lines:
…Now wole ȝe voche saue my lady dereGladly quod she and
                    said in þis manere

BodRawPoe141.First Lines:
WEl sayde bi corpus dominus quod oure ostLonge mot thou sire ryde
                    bi cost…
BodRawPoe141.Last Lines:
…Nou wol fouche saf my lady dereGladly quod she and seyde in
                    this manere
BodRawPoe141.Attributed Title: Here bigynneth the rehercyng of our Ost (f. 91); Oure Ost (RT)

CamTCC595.Transcription:
WElle seide by corpus dominus quod oure OsteNow longe mote thou saile
                    by the coosteYe gentille maistre gentille marynereGod yeue the monke a
                    thousand quade yereHa ha felawes beware of suche a iapeThe monke put
                    in the mannes hode an ApeAnd his wyffes eke by seynt AugustyneDraweth
                    no monkes nomore to your ynneBut nowe passe ouer and let vs seke
                    aboutWho nowe shalle first of alle this rowte
CamTCC595.Note:
VII.444-52 omitted (rest of the leaf blank with following folio
                    excised).
CamTCC595.Attributed Title:
…Beholdeth nowe the / mery seynge of oure worthy Oste to the Shipman
                    (f. 221v); Here begynneth Chaucers tale (f. 222; the prose
                        Melibee follows Prioress’s Tale)
